Award.AwardTitle: Phase II I/UCRC University of California-Davis: Center for Biophotonics Sensors and Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
CBSS operates at the intersection of life sciences and photonics engineering and focuses on precompetitive research that provides the enabling technologies for advanced methods to detect, sense and identify biological properties, conditions or changes at the molecular, cellular and subcellular level. These innovations will address solutions in the areas of Disease Diagnosis, Drug Efficacy Testing & Monitoring, Drug Discovery, and Food & Water Safety through long-term industrial partnerships with the CBSS members. During Phase II, research efforts will continue at Boston University (lead institution) and UC Davis (university site) to develop collaborations with faculty across our campuses whose research is relevant to the Center?s mission. The Center's research has the potential to advance knowledge by developing biosensing methods and applying them to important application areas defined by industry members to be of great demand in the marketplace. At the same time, industry participation will enhance the educational experiences of our pipeline of diverse scientist and engineers. Students have an opportunity to directly participate in the technology transfer process and with industry learn to identify applications and define areas of greatest needs, evaluate new technologies and research tools, and pursue research that can be applied to solving real-world challenges and improving healthcare outcomes. As CBSS grows, the Center intends to capitalize on a trend by companies in the life sciences sector to accelerate innovation through collaborative research and university-led innovations, specifically in the area of biophotonic sensing.

The Center's value to the membership is based on the ability to deliver pre-competitive research that can be adapted to align with a member's product portfolio long-term plans. This high priority research and product directed research typically remains the focus of each individual company, but collectively, the membership values the Center for:
- Adding to the breadth and diversity of a member's research portfolio.
- Working on pre-competitive technologies that could add some benefits in the future.
- Working on alternative approaches that have merit but which a member company has neither the time nor the resources to pursue. This also helps a member better position their existing product/technology approaches. Providing exposure to emerging areas of research that may be outside the company's domain, thus adding to a member?s innovation capability.

The research projects, guided by industry strategic oversight, will lead to breakthroughs in understanding cell/host interactions, new biomarker discovery, point-of-care and interoperation diagnostics, personalized cancer treatment, and many other technologies that will improve the quality of healthcare. The Center's research is aligned with three overlapping thrust areas: Bio-Imaging, Optical Diagnostics and Analytics, and each of these thrust areas has a component in Systems, Sensors & Devices, and Materials & Biology. The goal of the Analytics research is to embed data retrieval and computing processing power in imaging and diagnostic tools to develop an understanding of biological, genetic, behavioral and environmental data gathered so that healthcare decisions can be made down to the individual level. The UC Davis site will continue to leverage its scientific expertise, infrastructure and research capabilities to grow the toolbox of biophotonic sensors and systems and apply these new technologies towards better, faster, and more inexpensive healthcare. During Phase II, we plan to engage faculty from additional University of California campuses and thus further expand the Center/s research capabilities and expertise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Biophotonic Sensors and Systems (CBSS) was established as a Phase I NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) in 2011, and as a Phase II I/UCRC program in 2017, with the lead site at Boston University and a university site at UC Davis. The goal was to establish a national consortium where photonics provides enabling technologies for advances in methods to detect, sense, identify and understand biological properties, conditions, or changes at the molecular, cellular, and subcellular level. This early-stage research has applications and is expected to lead to significant commercial benefits in areas such as: disease diagnosis; drug discovery, screening, and efficacy testing; patient monitoring; food and water safety.

During Phase II (2017-2018), we attempted to build the membership but we encountered challenges; refined center processes for soliciting and reviewing proposals, and updated a technology roadmap, while constantly facilitating information sharing between industry and academia about unmet needs that pose societal challenges and the potential for new biosensing advances to provide technology solutions. The current research thrusts in CBSS are: Bioimaging, Optical Diagnostics, and Analytics, as detailed in the center?s technology roadmap.

For the reporting period, CBSS engaged more than 50 scientists, engineers, and business professionals at Boston University and UC Davis. Faculty from diverse colleges, schools, and graduate groups (medicine, engineering, physics, chemistry, biophysics, food and agricultural sciences) participated at the UC Davis site and contributed research expertise in spectroscopy, microscopy, imaging, single-molecule analysis, non-linear techniques, and more, as well as applications.

The Center had a total of 17 members, with the industry membership for CBSS decreasing to six members by the end of the reporting period. Collectively, the CBSS industry membership links the Center?s research to applications of high demand in the marketplace. For example, the need to decrease healthcare costs is a strong driver for developing non-invasive biosensing technologies, and methods that detect diseases in their earliest stages, when they are easiest and less costly to treat, and chances for successful treatments are the highest.

Notable Center accomplishments for the reporting period include:

  • 8 distinct research projects were supported by affiliated companies
  • 1 new patent was made available to affiliated companies
  • 13 publications were associated with CBSS funded research projects

At the UC Davis Site:

  • 1 graduate student, and 4 postdoc fellows received training

Here are some highlights of impacts to the field that are directly attributable to CBSS efforts at the UC Davis Site:

  • Scientists demonstrated proof-of-concept use of the one-bead one-compound (OBOC) platform to generate illuminating-peptide libraries, manufactured illuminating peptide microchips (morphine-sensitive sensor chip), and showed feasibility of a fluorescence-based sensor against opioids. The long-term goal is to develop a new point of care test for instant opioid detection, identification, and quantification.
  • Developed a robust, compact retinal imaging AO-OCT system with AO via pupil segmentation, to compare performance for several hardware and computational approaches
  • Conducted pre-clinical studies of Raman spectroscopy for in vivo and ex vivo probing of retina for drusen, in animal models of Age Related Macular Degeneration (AMD), with suppressed fluorescence background.

 

CBSS contributed to the nation?s research infrastructure base by supporting research at our university sites. The I/UCRC framework enables us to learn from industry what are the areas of greatest needs in terms of new technologies and research tools, and to pursue research that can be applied to solve real-world challenges, for significant societal impact.

Industry participation also enhances the educational experiences of our students at all levels, from undergraduate to graduate and postgraduate, and provides a pipeline of talented engineers and scientists to industry. Like its partners at Boston University, UC Davis is committed to developing the potential of all trainees, including underrepresented groups in STEM fields, by providing connections with companies for future employment, formal and informal mentorship, and facilitating internships with our I/UCRC partners, and referring our graduates and alumni for job openings that need highly specialized expertise.
